explanation:
1) struct UploadContext: The function immediately casts the parameter cls to struct UploadContext * (uc) and then reads/writes members (category, language, fd, filename, response). To determine whether any action in the function modifies one of the function parameters (or aliases them), the analyser must know the exact layout and types of the members (e.g. whether members alias or overlap with incoming parameter storage, or whether members are themselves the same object as a parameter). This is needed to decide whether modifications (uc->... = ...) are modifications of the pointer parameter itself (forbidden) or only of the object pointed to by cls (allowed).

2) do_append (declaration or macro definition): The code calls do_append(&uc->category, data, size). do_append might be a function or a macro; if it is a macro it could expand into code that assigns to local parameter identifiers (and thus could modify a function parameter variable). The declaration (or macro body) is required to determine whether calling it could modify any of process_upload_data's parameters (for MISRA the question is whether this function's parameters are modified within this function body, including via macros expanded inline).

3) request_refused_response and internal_error_response (declarations): These identifiers are assigned to uc->response. If these are macros (or have unusual definitions) they could expand to code that touches function parameters. Their declarations/definitions are needed to rule out any hidden macro expansion that assigns to or otherwise modifies the function parameters.

Note: All standard library functions used (strcmp, strstr, strchr, snprintf, open, write, strdup, fprintf, isprint, close, unlink, free, strerror, mkdir, etc.) are normally function calls and do not reassign the local parameter variables; however, if any of them are overridden as macros in the build environment, their macro definitions would also need to be inspected. The two items above (struct UploadContext and do_append) are the minimal, non-standard symbols required to confidently decide whether this function modifies its parameters.
